questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of swelling of her right breast for the past 4 days. She also reports malaise and some pain with breastfeeding. Over the past 2 days, she has been using over-the-counter analgesics and applying cabbage leaves and cooling pads on her breast without improvement of her symptoms. Three weeks ago, she delivered a healthy 3500-g (7.7-lb) girl. She has no history of serious illness. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 55 years. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows a tender, firm, swollen, erythematous right breast. Examination of the left breast shows no abnormalities. In addition to continuing cold compresses and analgesic therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Continue breastfeeding with the right breast and initiate dicloxacillin therapy
Continue breastfeeding with the right breast and initiate trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole therapy
Continue breastfeeding with the right breast
Stop breastfeeding with the right breast and perform ultrasonography
Stop breastfeeding with the right breast and perform surgical drainage
Stop breastfeeding with the right breast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mastitis may arise in the postpartum period as nipple fissures (from breastfeeding) facilitate the entry of bacteria and stagnant milk (due to overproduction or insufficient drainage) creates favorable conditions for bacterial growth within the lactiferous ducts. Initially, conservative treatment with analgesia and cold compresses is indicated. If there is no improvement within 12–24 hours of conservative treatment, an oral antibiotic that has strong activity against Staphylococcus aureus (the most common causative pathogen) and is safe during breastfeeding (e.g., dicloxacillin, cephalexin) is indicated. Mothers should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding with the affected breast in order to empty milk reserves and prevent a breast abscess from developing.

B) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) can be used to treat mastitis caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). However, due to the risk of kernicterus in the newborn, TMP/SMX should be avoided if possible. If initial treatment with the appropriate therapy is not effective and breast milk culture shows MRSA, clindamycin or TMP/SMX is the preferred alternative treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Continued breastfeeding with conservative treatment (cold compresses and analgesic therapy) is appropriate for the management of breast engorgement, which can manifest with tenderness, firmness, and fullness of the breast. However, breast engorgement is not associated with erythema and fever and usually occurs 3–5 days postpartum. This patient's fever and persistent symptoms lasting > 24 hours indicate severe mastitis, for which conservative treatment alone is insufficient.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient with mastitis, additional workup (e.g., imaging, breast milk cultures) are not routinely indicated. Ultrasonography is performed if the patient does not respond to empiric antibiotic therapy within 48–72 hours or if a breast abscess is suspected (the presence of a tender, fluctuant mass).

Breast imaging is also performed if breast cancer is suspected. Although the patient has a family history of breast cancer, and some breast carcinomas can manifest with erythema (Paget disease of the breast, inflammatory breast cancer), the patient does not present with features suggestive of those conditions such as a scaly rash, nipple retraction, or blood-tinged nipple discharge. Fever, pain with breastfeeding, and the acute nature of this patient's illness in the puerperal period are not consistent with breast cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

In the event the patient develops a tender, fluctuant mass suggestive of a breast abscess, surgical drainage is required. However, this patient shows no such finding and should instead receive treatment for mastitis.

F) INCORRECT:

Nursing mothers with mastitis should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding with both breasts every 2–3 hours to facilitate breast emptying, thereby reducing the risk of developing a breast abscess.
questions.hint: This nursing mother presents with a tender, firm, swollen, erythematous breast and fever 3 weeks after giving birth. These findings are suggestive of mastitis.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman reports a 2-day history of tenderness in the right breast. She may have had some fevers and chills but has not taken her temperature. She delivered a healthy boy at term by cesarean section 2 weeks ago and is breastfeeding exclusively.
On examination, her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, her heart rate is 92 beats per minute and regular, and her temperature is 39.1°C. Her left breast appears normal. The right breast has an erythematous area covering approximately 2 cm by 3 cm at the 7 o’clock position, 5 cm from the areola. The area is tender to palpation, nonfluctuant, and slightly indurated. The nipple of the right breast is cracked, but milk is expressed without difficulty. There is no visible pus in the breast milk.
Abdominal examination reveals the fundus to be barely palpable above the pubic symphysis; it is firm and nontender. The low horizontal scar above the pubic symphysis is clean, dry, and intact, without any erythema or tenderness.
Which one of the following recommendations is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Continue breastfeeding, initiate oral dicloxacillin, and perform incision and drainage
Continue breastfeeding and initiate oral amoxicillin
Pump and discard breast milk and initiate oral amoxicillin
Pump and discard breast milk, with no antibiotic therapy
Continue breastfeeding and initiate oral dicloxacillin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with mastitis should be counseled to continue breastfeeding to allow for continued neonatal nutrition and emptying of the affected breast. Incision and drainage is indicated for breast abscess, not mastitis. An abscess should be suspected with the presence of a palpable mass or after a failed trial of antibiotic treatment for mastitis and is diagnosed if the mass is obviously fluctuant or demonstrably cystic on ultrasound examination.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with mastitis should be counseled to continue breastfeeding to allow for continued neonatal nutrition and emptying of the affected breast. Amoxicillin treatment is not appropriate for an infection that may be caused by S. aureus because most isolates are resistant.

C) INCORRECT:

Pumping and discarding of breast milk (“pump and dump”) is not recommended because breastfeeding more efficiently empties the breast, and the milk is safe for the baby. Amoxicillin treatment is not appropriate for an infection that may be caused by S. aureus because most isolates are resistant.

D) INCORRECT:

Pumping and discarding of breast milk (“pump and dump”) is not recommended because breastfeeding more efficiently empties the breast, and the milk is safe for the baby.

E) CORRECT:

Mastitis can occur in up to 10% of women who are actively breastfeeding. Women with mastitis typically present during the second or third week after delivery with a unilaterally tender, hardened breast, chills, fever, and malaise. Common risk factors include sore or cracked nipples, difficulty breastfeeding, a history of mastitis, and diabetes mellitus.

Mastitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and can be treated successfully in the outpatient setting with a narrow-spectrum antibiotic, such as dicloxacillin or cephalexin. If the patient has risk factors for methicillin-resistant S. aureus, the clinician should consider an agent that is likely to have activity against this organism, such as clindamycin. Clindamycin can also be used if the patient has a clinically significant penicillin allergy.

Key learning point: A woman who is breastfeeding and develops mastitis should be counseled to continue breastfeeding and should be treated with dicloxacillin, cephalexin, or clindamycin.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman who has been breastfeeding her infant since normal vaginal delivery presents with a 2-week history of pain and redness in her right breast. She was evaluated in the emergency department 5 days ago for similar symptoms and was prescribed a 7-day course of cephalexin. She has no history of or risk factors for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection .
She has slightly more pain today than she had 5 days ago but has noticed no change in the redness or swelling. She continues to breastfeed her infant.
She is afebrile, has a blood pressure of 125/70 mm Hg, and has a heart rate of 80 beats per minute. The outer lower quadrant of the right breast is erythematous and warm to touch but not fluctuant.
Which one of the following interventions is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain a sample of breast milk for culture to guide antibiotic selection
Continue the cephalexin as initially prescribed
Discontinue breastfeeding and observe
Replace cephalexin with amoxicillin-clavulanate
Admit the patient for administration of intravenous cefazolin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Given that most cases of mastitis are caused by S. aureus, cultures are not usually indicated. Women who have risk factors for methicillin-resistant S. aureus infection, or who have a particularly severe infection or abscess formation, should be evaluated for this pathogen.

B) INCORRECT:

If first-line treatment with a cephalosporin is ineffective, the infection may be caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing staphylococci or another resistant organism, and the spectrum of coverage should be broadened. Amoxicillin-clavulanate offers a broader spectrum of coverage than cephalexin and is particularly effective against beta-lactamase-producing bacteria.

C) INCORRECT:

Women with mastitis should be encouraged to routinely empty the breast of milk (through either breastfeeding or pumping), as this has been shown to accelerate recovery.

D) CORRECT:

Mastitis refers to inflammation of the breast and is most commonly caused by infection with Staphylococcus aureus. It is particularly common in breastfeeding women and typically manifests with localized erythema and pain. When treated inadequately or left untreated, mastitis may become chronic, or an abscess may develop.

The evidence for any particular antibiotic being most effective for mastitis is scarce. Oral antibiotics with good staphylococcal coverage are usually sufficient, and first-line empiric treatment with dicloxacillin or a first-generation cephalosporin may be started. If first-line treatment is ineffective, the infection may be caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing staphylococci or another resistant organism, and the spectrum of coverage should be broadened.

Amoxicillin-clavulanate offers a broader spectrum of coverage than cephalexin and is particularly effective against beta-lactamase-producing bacteria. A minimum course of 10 to 14 days should be prescribed in refractory cases. Cefotetan (a second-generation cephalosporin with additional anti-anaerobe coverage) can also be used. Both drugs are safe for use in women who are breastfeeding.

Key learning point: Appropriate second-line antibiotic therapy for uncomplicated mastitis that does not respond to a cephalosporin consists of amoxicillin-clavulanate or cefotetan.

E) INCORRECT:

Hospitalization is not typically necessary for women with uncomplicated mastitis; it is reserved for advanced or severe cases, such as in patients presenting with sepsis.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents to the clinic 2 weeks postpartum with a 2-day history of a painful, swollen, and reddened area on her right breast. She reports mild fever and increased discomfort when nursing from the affected side. On examination, the area is warm, erythematous, and tender, with no palpable fluctuation. She is concerned about whether she should continue breastfeeding.
What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Urgent breast ultrasound to look for abscess
Immediate surgical drainage
Intravenous antibiotics and discontinue feeding from the affected breast
Oral anti-staphylococcal antibiotics and encourage continued breastfeeding

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound is useful for suspected abscesses, especially with palpable fluid collections or lack of improvement. However, the absence of a fluctuant mass makes immediate imaging unnecessary, as clinical assessment guides management.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical drainage is indicated for abscesses, characterized by a palpable fluctuant mass, which is absent here. The presentation suggests diffuse inflammation without pus collection, making invasive procedures unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotics are reserved for severe systemic symptoms or abscesses, which are not present. Discontinuing breastfeeding is inappropriate, as continued feeding aids milk drainage and prevents stasis, which can worsen the infection.

D) CORRECT:

Lactational mastitis manifests with localized breast pain, erythema, warmth, and systemic symptoms like fever, often due to Staphylococcus aureus infection from milk stasis and nipple trauma. The absence of fluctuance suggests no abscess, making oral antibiotics like dicloxacillin or cephalexin appropriate. Continued breastfeeding aids milk drainage, reduces stasis, and prevents abscess formation. Supportive measures, such as analgesics and warm compresses, enhance recovery.

Key learning point: In breastfeeding women with symptoms of mastitis, the initial management involves antibiotic therapy, such as flucloxacillin, to address the infection and prevent abscess formation.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic 2 weeks postpartum with a 2-day history of left breast pain, redness, and fever. She has been exclusively breastfeeding and reports increased engorgement in the affected breast. She tried warm compresses, but her symptoms worsened. Examination reveals a 5 × 5 cm area of erythema and tenderness on the left breast without a fluctuant mass. She is concerned about the safety of continuing to breastfeed and is requesting immediate relief (see lab result).

Temperature
38.4°C

Normal Values

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Antibiotics covering Staphylococcus aureus, continued breastfeeding, and breast ultrasound
Discontinue breastfeeding and start intravenous antibiotics
Immediate surgical drainage of the affected region
Cold compresses and defer antibiotics until further testing

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Postpartum mastitis is commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, often due to milk stasis and nipple trauma. Symptoms include fever, localized erythema, tenderness, and leukocytosis. Antibiotics such as dicloxacillin or cephalexin target S. aureus. Continuing breastfeeding helps drain the affected breast, reducing milk stasis and promoting recovery. Breast ultrasound, while not always necessary, can rule out abscess formation, especially if symptoms persist despite treatment. This approach combines pharmacologic and supportive management to effectively address postpartum mastitis.

Key learning point: In cases of lactational mastitis, antibiotics targeting Staphylococcus aureus are necessary, and a breast ultrasound should be performed to rule out an abscess.

B) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing breastfeeding in mastitis can worsen milk stasis and infection. Intravenous antibiotics are reserved for severe cases with systemic toxicity or abscess, neither of which are present here. Continuing breastfeeding aids in drainage and recovery.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical drainage is indicated for abscesses, which are not evident here due to the absence of a fluctuant mass. Mastitis without abscess is managed with antibiotics and continued breastfeeding to ensure milk drainage.

D) INCORRECT:

Cold compresses may reduce inflammation but can worsen milk stasis in mastitis. Delaying antibiotics in the presence of infection signs risks progression. Warm compresses and antibiotics are recommended for effective management.

Examination reveals a tender, firm, swollen, erythematous right breast. The left breast is normal. In addition to continuing cold compresses and analgesic therapy, which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Continue breastfeeding with the right breast and initiate dicloxacillin therapy.
Continue breastfeeding with the right breast.
Continue breastfeeding with the right breast and initiate trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole therapy.
Stop breastfeeding with the right breast.
Stop breastfeeding with the right breast and perform surgical drainage.

B) INCORRECT:

Continued breastfeeding along with conservative treatment methods, such as cold compresses and analgesics, is appropriate for managing breast engorgement, which can manifest with low-grade fever (< 38.4°C), tenderness, erythema, firmness, and fullness of the breast. However, breast engorgement usually affects both breasts and most often occurs 3–5 days postpartum. This patient's high-grade fever, flu-like symptoms (e.g., malaise), and persistent symptoms lasting > 24 hours indicate severe mastitis, for which conservative treatment alone is insufficient.

Nursing mothers with mastitis should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding with both breasts every 2–3 hours to facilitate breast emptying, thereby reducing the risk of developing a breast abscess.

E) INCORRECT:

If the patient develops a breast abscess that can not be treated with needle aspiration (e.g., a large abscess), surgical drainage is indicated. A breast abscess is suspected if a patient with mastitis has a tender, localized, fluctuant mass. This patient shows no such finding.
questions.hint: In nursing mothers, the sudden onset of unilateral breast tenderness, firmness, swelling, erythema, high fever, and flu-like symptoms (e.g., malaise) is consistent with puerperal mastitis. This condition most often occurs within 6 weeks postpartum.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with a 36-hour history of left breast pain, warmth, and redness. She delivered a healthy infant 4 weeks ago and has been exclusively breastfeeding. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Physical examination shows a tender, indurated, erythematous area without fluctuation on the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. She reports that warm compresses and ibuprofen have provided minimal relief. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discontinue breastfeeding and prescribe cephalexin
Obtain breast milk culture before initiating treatment
Continue breastfeeding and prescribe dicloxacillin
Perform breast ultrasound to rule out abscess
Continue supportive care and arrange follow-up in 24 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin is an appropriate antibiotic choice for mastitis, but breastfeeding should not be discontinued. Discontinuing breastfeeding promotes milk stasis and increases the risk for abscess formation.

B) INCORRECT:

Breast milk culture is not indicated for typical mastitis. Culture is reserved for patients with inadequate response to empiric therapy, severe infection, recurrent mastitis, or for when the infant is immunocompromised.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has mastitis with symptoms persisting beyond 24 hours despite supportive care, accompanied by fever. The most appropriate next step in management includes continuing on-demand breastfeeding to prevent milk stasis and initiating empiric antibiotic therapy with dicloxacillin.

D) INCORRECT:

Breast ultrasound is not routinely required for uncomplicated mastitis. Ultrasound is indicated when there is poor response to empiric antibiotic therapy or an abscess is suspected.

E) INCORRECT:

While supportive care is appropriate for early mastitis, antibiotic therapy is indicated when symptoms persist for more than 12–24 hours.
